text: VETS30031 / VETS90123 Animals in Extensive Production Systems Transition cow management David Beggs dbeggs@unimelb.edu.au Transition Period Energy Amount required yesterday = 6-7MJ If she produces 20 litres, Energy required tomorrow = 17MJ Calcium Before calving, a cow deposits 8-12g per day to her foetus After calving, Milk contains 12g per litre Transition period 4 weeks before to 4 weeks after calving Diet during this time is a major determinant of health and reproduction The “lactation curve” of a dairy cow 3 (Source: Elanco, 2009) The transition period It was discovered early that pre-calving nutrition could be used to prevent milk fever It was then discovered that pre-calving nutrition could be used to prevent (or cause) nearly everything else! 45 Hypocalcaemia – the “gateway disease”DCAD – Dietary cation-anion difference More properly DCAB (B=Balance) Diets are electrically neutral, with a balance of cations and anions Strong Ions are ones that are highly bioavailable and not metabolized DCAD theory DCAD = (Na + K) – (Cl + S) Less is more … “Anionic salts” added to the diet • ammonium chloride (NH4Cl), ammonium sulphate [(NH4)2SO4], CaCl2, calcium sulphate (CaSO4), magnesium chloride (MgCl2) and magnesium sulphate (MgSO4) Very small changes in blood pH Measurable changes in urine pH Small changes in blood pH can have large effects on parathyroid hormone receptivity and ultimately the risk of clinical milk fever 7 Source: Dairy Australia National Dairy Farmer Survey, 2011 (1,005 respondents) Time cows fed diet (base: those lead feeding) Transition feeding approaches used (base: those lead feeding) Transition cow management practices on Australian farms Lead feed Dairy Australia TCM resourcesAEPS – DAIRY WEEK 1 12
